proposals.reasoning: This lineup aligns with the broad consensus that’s formed: it’s a relatively low-heat combination that avoids stacking too many early-question-mark slots, keeps both Bob and Frank off for now to reduce immediate narrative pressure on them, and gives us a straightforward baseline read. With Alice and Grace under higher scrutiny and Charlie as a central info piece, we should get a cleaner early signal than if we mixed in more contentious picks right away.

votes.comment: Solid low-drama opener; as a known-good to myself I’m comfortable on it, and it keeps both Merlin-claim slots off early while still giving us useful info.
It’s a broadly supported low-heat opener; no strong reason to disrupt consensus this early.
I’m on the team and it’s a broadly accepted low-heat lineup, giving good information and keeping suspicion off me early.
There’s already an evil on this team and it’s widely accepted, so it’s a good early setup for us to gather info and potential sabotage later.
Solid low-drama opener with broad support; keeps contested slots like Bob and Frank off while giving us a clean early info read.
No known evil players on this team from my perspective; good low-risk opener for information.
Standard low-drama first mission team including me; no strong red flags yet and rejecting would give us less useful info than running it.
Early mission with no strong red flags; broad consensus plus information gain from seeing how this popular trio behaves is worth the risk.

discussion.content: For the first mission I’d lean toward a quieter, lower‑info team, maybe something like me plus two of Charlie/Diana/Eve, and leave both Bob and Frank off for now so we don’t paint a target on whoever’s good among them. Early on I mostly want a clean read, not a flashy lineup.
I’d rather avoid stacking too many of Charlie/Diana/Eve together with you, Alice—how about you, Eve, and me so we at least get one higher‑scrutiny slot on the first team?

I’d like at least one of Alice/Grace plus one of me/Frank on the first team so we’re not over‑centralizing reads on Bob and Eve right away. Something like Alice–Charlie–Grace feels like a lower‑drama way to get a baseline.

I’m fine staying off the first team, but from what’s been said so far Alice–Charlie–Grace feels like a reasonable low‑heat lineup to start with and gives us a cleaner signal than mixing in too many “question mark” slots at once.
Alice–Charlie–Grace seems like a fine low‑risk opener to me, and I’m a bit wary of how quickly Bob wanted onto the first team. I’m okay sitting this one out if it means we get a cleaner early read.

Alice–Charlie–Grace is about as low‑stress as we’re going to get for a first run: it spreads info without immediately empowering any of the more contested slots. I’d rather see how Bob and I behave from off the team first than lock either of us into an early narrative.

Alice–Charlie–Grace as a first team works for me, but the near‑unanimous enthusiasm for it makes me want to keep a close eye on who’s trying hardest to lock that in without considering alternatives. I’m especially noting Bob’s early push to get himself on a team versus everyone else being more willing to sit back.

I’m okay with Alice–Charlie–Grace as a starting team, but the almost universal comfort with it makes me think at least one evil is probably trying to coast on that consensus, so I’d like Alice and Grace especially to be ready to justify their later picks clearly.

proposals.reasoning: We should avoid repeating too many players from the failed first mission, so I’m only taking one of Alice/Charlie/Grace. Alice goes on as a test from that group, while Charlie and Grace both sit out after the fail. I include myself (Eve) plus Frank and Henry, who are all untested so far and were part of the more cautious suggestions in discussion. This lineup balances minimizing exposure to the suspected pool from Mission 1 while still giving us strong new information: if this team passes, suspicion narrows strongly onto Charlie/Grace (and possibly Diana/Bob for pushing the alternative core); if it fails, we can focus on the new group and re-evaluate Alice versus the rest of us.

votes.comment: I know I’m good, we avoid the Charlie/Grace pair from the failed mission, and if Frank is Merlin this is likely a safe spread; the team gives strong info either way.
No evil on this team; we can’t afford to let a likely all-good group through this early.

This dumps three completely untested players on at once while sidelining both Bob and me, which gives us very little ability to cross‑check overlaps with the first mission. I’d rather see a mix that reuses at least one of Bob/Frank with either me or Grace to get more structured info instead of a near‑fresh slate.

This puts three completely untested players together, which makes any result really hard to interpret. I’d rather see a lineup that includes Bob (and/or one of Charlie/Grace) so we’re cross-checking known overlaps instead of flying blind with a mostly new group.
Only one from the failed mission plus three untested players matches the cautious approach I argued for and gives strong info while avoiding the risky Charlie–Grace combo.
This avoids both Bob and Diana, and only repeats one player from the failed mission, which is a solid, low‑risk info-gathering team for Mission 2.
It only includes one of the Alice/Charlie/Grace group from the failed mission and adds three untested players, which fits my preference to avoid stacking suspects while getting new info.
This matches the cautious approach I argued for: only one of Alice/Charlie/Grace after the fail, plus three untested players, which should give clear info without overexposing the suspected group.

discussion.content: Given the fail on the first mission, I’m wary of Charlie and Grace going again together; I’d really like to see a team built around me plus some mix of Bob and Frank, since we need to start locking in people we feel are more likely to be good.

I don’t think we can automatically pin the fail on Charlie just because he was on the first team—Grace or even Diana could’ve played the fail—so I’d be okay with a team like Alice, me, Charlie, and Frank to cross‑check some of those overlaps.

I like Bob’s idea of Alice, Bob, me, and Frank — it keeps most people happy while giving us new info, and we really shouldn’t auto-clear Grace just because she’s pushing suspicion off herself. If this team passes clean, we can start narrowing the blame to whoever’s outside it.

I’m fine with a team like Alice, Bob, Charlie, and Frank as a good info-gathering compromise, but I’d really rather not see Charlie and Grace together again until we have more to go on from a second mission result.

I really don’t like putting both Alice and Charlie back on after a single‑fail mission — I’d rather see a team like Bob, Frank, me, and just one of the three from the first mission so we’re not doubling down on the same suspects.

Given the first mission already had a fail, I’d rather only bring one of Alice/Charlie/Grace back and mix in people who haven’t been tested yet, so something like Alice, Eve, Henry, and me feels like a safer spread. Bob and Diana both pushing hard for the same core makes me a bit nervous about just following that.

From my perspective I know I’m good, but since at least one of Alice/Charlie/me is almost certainly evil, I’d much rather see a team like Bob, Frank, Henry, and me (or swapping Henry for Eve) so we’re not stacking too many from that first mission again.

I really don’t want more than one of Alice/Charlie/Grace on this mission after that fail, so I like something like Frank’s suggestion of Alice, Eve, Frank, and me as a cleaner test group. If we really want Bob’s info in the mix, I’d swap him in for Alice rather than doubling up suspects.

proposals.reasoning: Mission 2 with Alice, Eve, Frank, and Henry succeeded with no fails, making this the cleanest-tested group so far. Reusing that exact team minimizes new uncertainty while avoiding players from the failed Mission 1 (Charlie, Grace) and also avoids introducing completely untested players whose alignment is unknown. Keeping the proven-successful core together gives the best chance of another success this round.

votes.comment: Same composition as the only clean mission so far and avoids the clearly suspicious Mission 1 overlap; from my perspective this is the lowest-uncertainty option right now.
All four have already been tested together and produced a clean success; repeating an unchanged, likely-good block is too safe for good.
I’d rather keep the Eve/Frank/Henry core but add Bob instead of re-adding Alice from the failed first mission, which still feels riskier to me.
All four are likely good and contain none of my evil teammates; I don’t want a clean good team going on this mission.
Alice was on the only failed mission and most players prefer the cleaner Eve/Frank/Henry core plus Bob; re-adding Alice risks repeating the earlier failure.
Same lineup as the only clean mission so far and excludes everyone from the failed team and any completely untested players, so it’s currently the safest option.
Mission 2 with this exact team succeeded with no fails, and the only clear suspicion so far is on the Mission 1 overlap (Charlie/Grace). This lineup is currently the safest-known option.
Alice was on the failed Mission 1, so reusing her over adding a fresh player like Bob risks repeating that hidden evil; I prefer the cleaner-looking core Eve/Frank/Henry plus Bob.

proposals.reasoning: Mission 1 (Alice, Charlie, Grace) had exactly one fail, so from my perspective at least one of Alice or Charlie is evil and I know I’m good, which clears me personally from causing that fail. Mission 2 (Alice, Eve, Frank, Henry) succeeded with no fails, which makes the core of Eve/Frank/Henry look relatively safer than players who haven’t been on a mission yet or were tied directly to the failed team. As the only alignment I know for sure is my own (good), the safest construction I can make is to reuse the proven-success core of Eve/Frank/Henry and add myself, rather than introducing a completely untested player like Bob or re-using Alice, who is still entangled with the failed Mission 1 team.

votes.comment: Grace is tied to the failed Mission 1, and most players preferred adding Bob to the Eve/Frank/Henry core instead of reusing someone from the suspicious first team.
I still don’t like re‑using Grace from the failed Mission 1 when we have the clean Mission 2 core available plus an untested option like me instead.
This team likely has few or no evils on it; I’d rather push for a lineup including someone from the earlier preferred core that adds a new face like Bob instead of Grace.
All four proposed players are likely good; as evil I don’t want a clean all-good team to go.
This reintroduces Grace from the failed Mission 1 when we could keep the clean Eve/Frank/Henry core and add a fresh player like Bob instead.

Eve/Frank/Henry are as clean as we can get from the success on Mission 2, and while Grace is somewhat suspicious from Mission 1, this is still safer than bringing in an untested Bob over that proven core.

I know I’m good, so the Mission 1 fail must be Alice or Charlie, not me. Reusing the clean Mission 2 core (Eve/Frank/Henry) plus myself is safer than reintroducing Alice or adding completely untested Bob.
Grace was on the only failed mission, so including her over a neutral like Bob is unnecessary risk; I’d rather keep Eve/Frank/me and add Bob instead.

proposals.reasoning: Mission 1 (Alice, Charlie, Grace) failed with 1 FAIL, so at least one of them is likely evil. Mission 2 (Alice, Eve, Frank, Henry) succeeded with 0 FAILs, so the cleanest core we have is Eve, Frank, and me (Henry). To minimize overlap with the failed Mission 1 and avoid the ambiguity around Alice, I’ll keep the proven Mission 2 core and add a fresh, previously untested player who wasn’t on Mission 1: Bob. This matches the strongest table consensus, avoids the Charlie/Grace overlap from the failed team, and uses the most trustworthy information we have so far.

votes.comment: Mission 2’s Eve/Frank/Henry core is our cleanest info so far, and swapping out Alice (overlaps the failed Mission 1) for fresh Bob avoids the Charlie/Grace suspicion while matching table consensus; this is likely our best shot right now.
I’m on the team and it’s otherwise the trusted Mission 2 core, giving us a great chance to sabotage while looking clean.
Matches the widely trusted Mission 2 core while avoiding the suspicious Mission 1 overlap; this is the most consensus-backed team so far.
Bob is evil and on the team while the rest look trusted, so getting this mission approved gives us a strong chance to sabotage without much suspicion.

Eve/Frank/Henry are the cleanest core from the successful Mission 2, and this team avoids all three suspects from the failed Mission 1 (Alice/Charlie/Grace). Bob is untested but this is the most information-consistent team so far.

Bob is completely untested, while the Mission 2 result makes Alice look much safer than either Charlie or Grace. I’d rather stick with the proven Eve/Frank/Henry core and retest with Alice than introduce a brand‑new unknown on a 4‑person mission.

Eve, Frank, and Henry come from the only clean mission so far (0 fails), and this team avoids the suspicious Mission 1 overlap with Alice/Charlie/Grace while testing an unproven Bob. This is currently the safest-looking option for good.
Keeps the clean Mission 2 core of Eve/Frank/Henry while avoiding the suspicious Mission 1 overlap (Alice/Charlie/Grace); Bob is the safest new add given current info.

discussion.content: Given the fail on the first mission, I really don’t want both Charlie and Grace going again, and the second team felt a lot cleaner, so I’d like to keep most of that core—especially Frank—while minimizing overlap with Mission 1.

I really like keeping the Mission 2 core together—Eve, Frank, Henry felt clean—so I’d be happy with those three plus me, since I haven’t been on anything yet and we avoid the Charlie/Grace overlap from the failed first team.

I’m fine sitting out this one—given the fail on Mission 1, I think the safest assumption is that at least one of me/Grace is bad, and between the two I’m a bit more suspicious of Grace. Sticking with the Mission 2 core plus a fresh face like Bob feels like a reasonable compromise.

I agree Mission 2 looked a lot cleaner, and I really don’t want to repeat the Charlie/Grace overlap from the failed first team. Eve, Frank, Henry plus Bob feels like a solid mix of “proven” and “untested” without touching the sketchy bits.
I’m happy keeping the Mission 2 core of me, Frank, and Henry, and I’d rather add Bob than repeat Alice given she was on the failed first team. So I’d back a team of Eve, Frank, Henry, and Bob here.

Mission 2 felt the cleanest to me so far, so I definitely want to keep Eve/Frank/Henry together, but I’m a little uneasy about adding a completely untested Bob when we could re‑try Alice with that core and see if the result stays clean.
From my perspective Mission 1 makes either Alice or Charlie (or both) look bad, so I’d rather avoid that overlap and go with the Mission 2 core of Eve/Frank/Henry plus Bob this round.
I like keeping the Mission 2 core of Eve/Frank/me, but since Mission 1 already failed with Alice on it, I’d rather add Bob here to minimize overlap with that first team.

proposals.reasoning: Mission 2 with Alice, Eve, Frank, and Henry was a clean success with 0 fails, which strongly suggests that block is mostly (and possibly entirely) good. The only change between Mission 2 (success) and Mission 3 (fail) was swapping Alice out for Bob, which makes Bob the most suspicious from that comparison. Mission 1 failed with the team Alice, Charlie, and Grace, and since I know I’m good, that points to at least one of Charlie or Grace being evil—so I want to avoid both of them if possible. Diana hasn’t appeared on a mission yet and isn’t implicated by any fail, making her the safest neutral addition. So this team keeps the proven-successful Mission 2 core (Alice, Eve, Frank, Henry) and adds the least-tainted outside player (Diana) while avoiding the main suspicion clusters (Bob, and at least one of Charlie/Grace).

votes.comment: Best use of the clean Mission 2 core (Alice–Eve–Frank–Henry) plus the least-tainted outsider, Diana; avoids Bob and the C/Grace cluster linked to previous fails.
Has an evil on it and only needs one fail to win, so we want this mission to go through.
Fits the Mission 2 core logic I supported earlier, and having Diana on the team makes it look balanced while testing a new player.
I’m on the team and can ensure it doesn’t pass cleanly, while the reasoning aligns with popular suspicion away from my teammates.

Mission 2’s A–E–F–H block is our strongest info: a 4-person clean success, then swapping Alice for Bob produced a fail on Mission 3, heavily implicating Bob over that core. Adding neutral Diana (on no failed team) avoids the M1 suspects (Charlie/Grace) and the M3 suspect (Bob). With mission 4 needing two fails, even a single hidden spy here can’t sink it alone, so this is our safest high-information team.
This overloads on the E/F/H block that produced the last fail and adds an untested player instead of using the chance to diversify and better isolate where the spy is.

Given mission 1 (Alice, Charlie, Grace) failed and I know I’m good, at least one of Alice/Charlie is evil. Mission 3 (Bob, Eve, Frank, Henry) also has at least one evil among Eve/Frank/Henry. So the proposed team (Alice, Eve, Frank, Henry, Diana) is guaranteed to contain at least one spy, while there’s a consistent scenario where swapping Diana for me (Alice, Eve, Frank, Henry, Grace) is fully good. I don’t want this version that excludes me and keeps a guaranteed spy.
Best use of the clean M2 core while dodging main suspicion clusters (Bob, Charlie, Grace); Diana is the least-tainted fifth, so this is our most reasonable shot right now.

discussion.content: Given the clean result from Mission 2 and the fail on Mission 3, I’m most inclined to trust Frank (and probably Henry/Eve) and stay away from Bob plus at least one of Charlie/Grace. For this mission I’d like a core of people from Mission 2, with me and Frank on it.

If we assume Mission 2 was clean, then the fail on Mission 3 points to at least one of Eve/Frank/Henry being bad, so we shouldn’t just auto‑trust that whole block. I’d rather build around Alice plus two from Mission 2 and then fill the last spots from outside the Mission 3 team.

I like the idea of building around Mission 2, but I don’t think we should completely write off everyone from Mission 3—Bob feels shadiest there, so I’d lean toward a team like Alice, Frank, Diana, me, plus one of Eve or Henry. That way we keep a strong core from the successful mission while testing a couple of the more neutral players.

I’m pretty wary of Bob after that Mission 3 fail, so I’d rather lean on the fully clean Mission 2 block and just add one person from outside it—something like Alice, Eve, Frank, Henry, and me feels like a solid, low‑risk team.

Given M2 was clean and the only change to get the M3 fail was swapping Alice for Bob, I’m very suspicious of Bob and would back something like Diana’s suggestion of Alice, me, Frank, Henry, and Diana, with the understanding that if that fails we know the spy is in the E/F/H block.

Leaning on Mission 2 makes sense to me, but if we think the key change for the fail on Mission 3 was adding Bob, I’d be more comfortable with something like Alice, Eve, me, Henry, and one of Charlie/Grace rather than bringing Bob or Diana back in right now. That keeps the clean core while testing someone new without overloading the team with people from the failed mission.
From my perspective Mission 2 clears Alice, Eve, Frank, and Henry, and since I know I’m good that makes Charlie and Bob look the worst, so I’d back a team of Alice, Eve, Frank, Henry, and me.

Given M2 was clean and I know I’m good, I want to stick with that core of Alice–Eve–Frank–me and add just one person from outside it, which makes Diana the safest fifth since she wasn’t on either failed team.
